title: Here’s why despite exercising women gain weight post-pregnancy | health and fitness | Hindustan Times
text:
London Researchers advise new mothers to cut down calories and work out more to lose weight post-pregnancy. (Shutterstock) 
Continuing to gain weight post-pregnancy? Do not put the blame on your pregnancy, but on your lifestyle choices post-delivery, say researchers. 
The findings showed that mothers keep the weight on by eating food off their child’s plate or sitting down for longer periods of time. Further, sleep deprivation – often found in new mothers – increases food cravings and appetite even if they want to follow a healthy diet, which further leads to weight gain. Read more Fruit and vegetable-rich diet can reduce lung disease risk in smokers 
“Mothers tend to put the needs of their children first, so they might not be exercising or taking care of themselves,” lead author Olga Yakusheva, associate professor at the University of Michigan in the US, told dailymail.co.uk. 
“It might also be little things like finishing the food on their child’s plate or spending more time sitting with their kids reading or watching a movie,” Yakusheva added. In addition, many women really crank up their diet and exercise for a short time. When they don’t see any results, they get discouraged and abandon exercise all together. Read more Don’t go easy on that paunch. You may be at higher risk for heart disease, diabetes 
However, if women want to lose the weight, they should cut the calories and work out more as well as take a holistic approach focused on a long-term healthy lifestyle, the research suggested. 
For the study, the team looked at data for 30,000 women who had given birth between one and four times. Although all the women gained weight due to their age, there was a sharp difference between those who gave birth and those who did not. 
By the time their babies became toddlers, mothers who had given birth had put on at least one pound more each year than those who were childless.
